channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Trump Approves the Epstein Files Release, but Some May Be Withheld
item.description: The president sought to take credit for the legislation, despite months of pressure to kill it. The bill has significant exceptions that could mean many documents would stay confidential.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Frantz for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump said he has signed legislation calling on the Justice Department to release its Epstein files.

item.title: Larry Summers to Stop Teaching at Harvard While It Investigates His Epstein Ties
item.description: The former Harvard president had previously stepped down from other positions following revelations about his longtime connections to Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Mark Arsenault and Mike Isaac
item.media:description: Lawrence Summers at a commencement ceremony at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass., in 2006.

item.title: Nvidia Earnings Show Profit Jumped 65% to $31.9 Billion
item.description: The company, which makes the computer chips essential to the artificial intelligence boom, also said revenue in its recent quarter rose to $57 billion.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jensen Huang, the chief executive of Nvidia, made a bet on chips for artificial intelligence that has turned his company into a Silicon Valley giant.

item.title: Nvidia Earnings Fuel Rally in Global Technology Stocks
item.description: The chipmaker’s profit surge and strong revenue forecast helped to ease fears that spending on A.I. infrastructure might be outpacing demand.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis and Joe Rennison
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: A trader on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange on Wednesday. In the United States, Nvidia shares climbed more than 5 percent in after-hours trading.

item.title: Trump and Mamdani Will Meet at White House on Friday
item.description: The meeting between Zohran Mamdani, the mayor-elect of New York City, and President Trump will come after the two men have fiercely attacked one another.
item.dc:creator: Emma G. Fitzsimmons
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani said he wanted to speak plainly to the president. President Trump, in a social media post, called Mr. Mamdani a communist.

item.title: Lindsey Halligan Admits Grand Jury Never Saw Final Comey Indictment
item.description: Grand jurors have to vote on indictments to approve them, but a prosecutor told the judge in the case that only the foreperson formally approved the second charging document, a move that could cripple the case.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Devlin Barrett
item.media:description: President Trump has consistently attacked James B. Comey since firing him as F.B.I. director in May 2017.

item.title: Stalled Contempt Inquiry Into Deportation Flights Springs Back to Life
item.description: The resurrected inquiry could finally get to the bottom of lingering questions such as: Did top Trump administration officials purposely ignore a court order?
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.media:description: Judge James E. Boasberg’s initial order laying out the contempt investigation outlined an aggressive process for figuring out what happened inside the administration.

item.title: Saudi Arabia’s Prince Has Big Plans, but His Giant Fund Is Low on Cash
item.description: After nearly a decade of expensive, hit-and-miss investments, Mohammed bin Salman is overseeing a behind-the-scenes restructuring of the kingdom’s all-important wealth fund.
item.dc:creator: Rob Copeland and Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: President Trump welcomed Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia to the White House on Tuesday.

item.title: Saudi Arabia, Once Shunned, Has Corporate Titans Swooning for Deals
item.description: Some of the most prominent U.S. executives gathered at the Kennedy Center for an event promoting deal-making with the oil-rich kingdom.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:description: President Trump posing next to Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia for a group photo at the U.S.-Saudi Investment Forum at the Kennedy Center in Washington.

item.title: Climate Change Is Stressing Italy’s Cows, and Coming for Your Burrata
item.description: Extreme heat causes cows to produce less milk. This poses problems in cheese-obsessed Italy, especially as it tries to meet growing demand for favorites like burrata.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Gianni Cipriano

item.title: George Clooney, Adam Sandler and Noah Baumbach on Fame and ‘Jay Kelly’
item.description: The stars and the director look back on their days trying to break into the industry and how failure was part of the equation.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan and Chantal Anderson
item.media:credit: Chantal Anderson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Noah Baumbach with Sandler and Clooney in Beverly Hills.

item.title: U.S.-Russian Peace Plan Would Force Ukraine to Cede Land and Cut Army
item.description: The 28-point proposal, which comes as the Trump administration tries to restart settlement talks, includes demands long rejected by Kyiv as nonstarters.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Maria Varenikova
item.media:description: A Ukrainian artillery unit firing a howitzer at Russian targets in the Dnipropetrovsk region, last month.

item.title: After the Death of Two Titans, Where Are the Next Giant Art Patrons?
item.description: With the passing of Leonard A. Lauder and Agnes Gund amid financial headwinds, arts organizations worry that the cultural megadonor may be a thing of the past.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.media:credit: Rebecca Smeyne for The New York Times

item.title: Robert L. Stirm, Returning P.O.W. in Pulitzer-Winning Photo, Dies at 92
item.description: The image immortalized a Vietnam veteran’s joyous homecoming to his beaming family, but it hid the truth about an unraveling marriage.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Lt. Col. Robert L. Stirm on March 17, 1973, as he was greeted by his family at Travis Air Force Base in Fairfield, Calif., after five and a half years as a prisoner of war in North Vietnam. His daughter Lorrie, foreground, is followed by the other children, Robert, Cynthia and Roger, and his wife, Loretta.

item.title: Franco Died 50 Years Ago, but He’s Still Winning New Fans in Spain
item.description: Young Spaniards are increasingly drawn to the dictator Francisco Franco. So the government is designing apps, games and T-shirts to promote democracy.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Maria Contreras Coll
item.media:description: Francisco Franco’s grave outside Madrid still draws mourners, highlighting lingering disputes within Spanish society over the dictator’s legacy. José Luis Ortiz, a Franco supporter, tends to the tomb.

item.title: NASA Releases Images of Comet 3I/ATLAS Passing by Mars
item.description: With the government reopened, the space agency at last released pictures captured by a fleet of government spacecraft of an object that came from beyond our solar system.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang

item.title: Thanksgiving Pies So Good, You’ll Want to Skip Dinner
item.description: Go straight to the good stuff this Thanksgiving: apple and cream, chocolate espresso, honeyed cranberry and more.
item.dc:creator: Sue Li, Johnny Miller and Sue Li and Sarah Smart

item.title: No, Mr. President, We Cannot ‘Leave It at That’
item.description: Working with imperfect partners does not mean that the United States should cover up and lie about their misdeeds.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: The White House Gold Rush Is On
item.description: They came bearing gifts. They left with what they wanted.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie

item.title: Is Your Community Becoming More Divided?
item.description: We want to hear about the ways in which the country’s politics are affecting your neighborhood, in ways big or small.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Florida Lawmaker Stole FEMA Funds for House Campaign, Prosecutors Say
item.description: Representative Sheila Cherfilus-McCormick misused $5 million in Covid-related funds during the pandemic in part to finance her campaign, according to the Justice Department.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler
item.media:credit: Tom Williams/CQ-Roll Call, Inc via Getty Images
item.media:description: Representative Sheila Cherfilus-McCormick has since 2022 represented a district that includes parts of Broward and Palm Beach Counties.

item.title: Top National Book Awards Go to Writing About the Middle East
item.description: Rabih Alameddine’s “The True True Story of Raja the Gullible (and His Mother)” won in fiction, while Omar El Akkad’s reckoning with Gaza took the nonfiction prize.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth A. Harris
item.category: The True True Story of Raja the Gullible (and His Mother) (Book)
One Day, Everyone Will Have Always Been Against This (Book)
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Omar El Akkad accepting the 2025 National Book Award for nonfiction on Wednesday night.

item.title: Alice and Ellen Kessler, ’60s Singing Sensations, Die at 89
item.description: The twin sisters from Germany, who were nightclub stars and regular guests on international variety shows, chose to end their lives together.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: The Kesslers at a news conference in 1997, presenting excerpts from a show based on their autobiography, “Eins Und Eins Ist Eins” (“One Plus One Is One”).

item.title: F.B.I. Hunt Intensifies for Ryan Wedding, Snowboarder Accused of Being a Drug Kingpin
item.description: Ryan Wedding, a former Olympic athlete said to be a major cocaine trafficker, is accused of ordering the murder of a witness who was set to testify against him.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Ryan Wedding during the Salt Lake City Winter Olympics in 2002.
